name: bomb
content:
bomb

noun
 
 
/bɒm/
 
/bɑːm/
Idioms
jump to other results
  1.  
     [countable] a weapon designed to explode at a particular time or when it is dropped or thrown
    • a bomb goes off/explodes
    • Hundreds of bombs were dropped on the city.
    • to plant/detonate a bomb
    • a suicide bomb
    • a roadside bomb (= one that is designed to blow up vehicles)
    • a bomb attack/blast
    • extensive bomb damage
    see also atomic bomb, cherry bomb, dirty bomb, pipe bomb
    Extra Examples
    • A terrorist bomb ripped through the town's packed shopping centre.
    • Eighty people died when bombs rained down on the city's crowded streets.
    • Enemy planes dropped bombs along the railway line.
    • He used a clock to make a home-made bomb.
    • India started to build a nuclear bomb.
    • Police suspect terrorists planted the bomb.
    • The bombs were strapped to their chests.
    • The land was scarred with bomb craters.
    • The plane had been adapted to carry bombs.
    • The suspect was apprehended for planting a fake bomb in a bus terminal.
    • Their truck was hit by a stray bomb.
    • a practice flight with dummy bombs
    • There was no warning of the bomb blast which ripped through the packed station.
    • On a pleasure trip from Umbria to Milan, a terrorist bomb goes off in Emily 's train carriage.
    Topics War and conflictb1
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • big
    • huge
    • large
    • …
    verb + bomb
    • place
    • plant
    • put
    • …
    bomb + verb
    • fall
    • rain
    • rain down
    • …
    bomb + noun
    • attack
    • blast
    • explosion
    • …
    See full entry
  2. the bomb
     [singular] nuclear weapons (atomic or hydrogen bombs)
    • countries that have the bomb
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • big
    • huge
    • large
    • …
    verb + bomb
    • place
    • plant
    • put
    • …
    bomb + verb
    • fall
    • rain
    • rain down
    • …
    bomb + noun
    • attack
    • blast
    • explosion
    • …
    See full entry
  3. a bomb
     [singular] (British English, informal) a lot of money
    • That dress must have cost a bomb!
    • Some company directors make an absolute bomb.
    Topics Moneyc2
  4. a bomb
     [singular] (North American English, informal) a complete failure
    • The musical was a complete bomb on Broadway.
    Topics Difficulty and failurec2
  5. [countable] (North American English) (in American football) a long forward throw of the ballTopics Sports: ball and racket sportsc2
  6. [countable] (North American English) a container in which a liquid such as paint or insect poison is kept under pressure and released as a spray or as foam
    • a bug bomb (= used for killing insects)
    More Like This Silent lettersSilent letters

    7. Word Originlate 17th cent.: from French bombe, from Italian bomba, probably from Latin bombus ‘booming, humming’, from Greek bombos, of imitative origin.
see also F-bomb
Idioms
be the bomb
  1. (North American English) to be very good; to be the best
    • Check out the new website. It's the bomb!
go down a bomb | go (like) a bomb
  1. (British English) to be very successful
    • Our performance went down a bomb.
    • The party was really going (like) a bomb.
    • Her new novel is going like a bomb (= selling well).
    Topics Successc2
go like a bomb
  1. (British English) (of a vehicle) to go very fast
See bomb in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee bomb in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: bomb

name: bomb
content:
bomb

verb
 
 
/bɒm/
 
/bɑːm/
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they bomb
 
/bɒm/
 
/bɑːm/
he / she / it bombs
 
/bɒmz/
 
/bɑːmz/
past simple bombed
 
/bɒmd/
 
/bɑːmd/
past participle bombed
 
/bɒmd/
 
/bɑːmd/
-ing form bombing
 
/ˈbɒmɪŋ/
 
/ˈbɑːmɪŋ/
Phrasal Verbs
jump to other results
  1.  
     [transitive] bomb something/somebody to attack something/somebody by leaving a bomb in a place or by dropping bombs from a plane
    • Warplanes bombed targets in and around the capital.
    • They have deliberately bombed civilians.
    • The city was heavily bombed in the war.
    Topics War and conflictb1, Crime and punishmentb1
    Extra Examples
    • The group had planned to bomb several foreign embassies.
    • Fighter jets bombed the road to the airport.
    • Terrorists bombed several army barracks.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadverb
    • heavily
    • accidentally
    • mistakenly
    • …
    See full entry
  2. [intransitive] + adv./prep. (British English, informal) to move very fast, especially in a vehicle, in a particular direction
    • They were bombing down the road at about 80 miles an hour.
  3. [transitive, intransitive] bomb (something) (North American English, informal) to fail a test or an exam very badly
    • The exam was impossible! I definitely bombed it.
    Topics Difficulty and failurec2
  4. [intransitive] (informal) (of a play, show, etc.) to fail very badly
    • His latest musical bombed and lost thousands of dollars.
    Topics Difficulty and failurec2
    5. Word Originlate 17th cent.: from French bombe, from Italian bomba, probably from Latin bombus ‘booming, humming’, from Greek bombos, of imitative origin.
Phrasal Verbs
  • be bombed out
See bomb in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee bomb in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English

name: A-bomb

A-bomb

noun
 
/ˈeɪ bɒm/
 
/ˈeɪ bɑːm/

jump to other results
  1. a bomb that explodes using the energy that is produced when an atom or atoms are splitTopics War and conflictc2

name: F-bomb
content:
F-bomb

noun
 
/ˈef bɒm/
 
/ˈef bɑːm/
[singular] (informal)
jump to other results
  1. used instead of the offensive swear word ‘fuck’ because you do not want to say it
    • She dropped the F-bomb on live TV!
    compare F-word
Check pronunciation: F-bomb

name: H-bomb
content:
H-bomb

noun
 
/ˈeɪtʃ bɒm/
 
/ˈeɪtʃ bɑːm/
(also hydrogen bomb)
jump to other results
  1. a very powerful nuclear bombTopics War and conflictc2
    Word Origin1950s: from H (denoting hydrogen) + bomb.
See H-bomb in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: bomb bay

bomb bay

noun
 
/ˈbɒm beɪ/
 
/ˈbɑːm beɪ/
jump to other results
  1. a part of an aircraft in which bombs are held and from which they can be dropped

name: car bomb
content:
car bomb

noun
 
/ˈkɑː bɒm/
 
/ˈkɑːr bɑːm/
jump to other results
  1. a bomb hidden inside or under a car
    • a car bomb attack outside the embassy
    • Fifteen people were blown to pieces by the car bomb.
    Topics War and conflictc1
See car bomb in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: car bomb

name: bomb site
content:
bomb site

noun
 
/ˈbɒm saɪt/
 
/ˈbɑːm saɪt/
jump to other results
  1. an area where all the buildings have been destroyed by bombs
    • The kids used to play on an old bomb site.
    • The electricians only left yesterday—the house still looks like a bomb site.
See bomb site in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: bomb site

name: mail bomb
content:
mail bomb

noun
 
/ˈmeɪl bɒm/
 
/ˈmeɪl bɑːm/
jump to other results
  1. (North American English)
    (also letter bomb British and North American English)
    a small bomb that is sent to somebody hidden in a letter that explodes when the envelope is opened
  2. an extremely large number of email messages that are sent to somebody

name: pipe bomb
content:
pipe bomb

noun
 
/ˈpaɪp bɒm/
 
/ˈpaɪp bɑːm/
jump to other results
  1. a bomb that somebody makes themselves and that is contained in a pipe
    • They narrowly escaped death when a pipe bomb exploded under a seat in their car.
Check pronunciation: pipe bomb

name: time bomb
content:
time bomb

noun
 
/ˈtaɪm bɒm/
 
/ˈtaɪm bɑːm/
jump to other results
  1. a bomb that can be set to explode at a particular time
  2. a situation that is likely to cause serious problems in the future
    • Rising unemployment is a political time bomb for the government.
    • He described global warming as ‘an environmental time bomb ticking away’.
See time bomb in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: time bomb

name: bomb alert
content:
bomb alert

noun
 
/ˈbɒm əlɜːt/
 
/ˈbɑːm əlɜːrt/
(British English)
(also bomb scare British and North American English, bomb threat especially in North American English)
jump to other results

name: bomb scare
content:
bomb scare

noun
 
/ˈbɒm skeə(r)/
 
/ˈbɑːm sker/
(also bomb threat especially in North American English)
(British English also bomb alert)
jump to other results
  1. an occasion when somebody says that they have put a bomb somewhere and everyone has to leave the area
    • The building was evacuated after a bomb scare.
See bomb scare in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

carpet-bomb

verb
 
/ˈkɑːpɪt bɒm/
 
/ˈkɑːrpɪt bɑːm/
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they carpet-bomb
 
/ˈkɑːpɪt bɒm/
 
/ˈkɑːrpɪt bɑːm/
he / she / it carpet-bombs
 
/ˈkɑːpɪt bɒmz/
 
/ˈkɑːrpɪt bɑːmz/
past simple carpet-bombed
 
/ˈkɑːpɪt bɒmd/
 
/ˈkɑːrpɪt bɑːmd/

/ˈkɑːpɪt bɒmd/

/ˈkɑːpɪt bɒmɪŋ/
 
/ˈkɑːrpɪt bɑːmɪŋ/
jump to other results
  1. carpet-bomb something to drop a large number of bombs onto every part of an area
  2. carpet-bomb somebody (business) to send an advertisement to a very large number of people, especially by email
    • They carpet-bombed the public with commercials for their product.

name: cherry bomb

cherry bomb

noun
 
/ˈtʃeri bɒm/
 
/ˈtʃeri bɑːm/
(North American English)
jump to other results
  1. a small, round, red firecracker that explodes with a very loud noise
    • Two fans were injured after a cherry bomb was thrown at them.
    • (figurative) In her new movie, Weaver is a cherry bomb about to explode.
